edit target content:
The AI chip and supercomputer supply chain is complex, demanding the most advanced manufacturing, packaging, assembly, and test technologies. NVIDIA is partnering with Amkor and SPIL for packaging and testing operations in Arizona.

Within the next four years, NVIDIA plans to produce up to half a trillion dollars of AI infrastructure in the United States through partnerships with TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. These world-leading companies are deepening their collaboration with NVIDIA, expanding their businesses, global footprint, and strengthening supply chain resilience.
content after edit:
The AI chip and supercomputer supply chain relies on highly advanced manufacturing, packaging, assembly, and testing technologies. NVIDIA is partnering with Amkor and SPIL to establish packaging and testing operations in Arizona, supporting U.S.-based production.

Over the next four years, NVIDIA aims to deliver up to $500 billion in AI infrastructure within the United States through strategic partnerships with TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. These global industry leaders are expanding their collaboration with NVIDIA, thereby strengthening their global presence and increasing supply chain resilience.

edit target content:
The AI chip and supercomputer supply chain is complex, demanding the most advanced manufacturing, packaging, assembly, and test technologies. NVIDIA is partnering with Amkor and SPIL for packaging and testing operations in Arizona.

Within the next four years, NVIDIA plans to produce up to half a trillion dollars of AI infrastructure in the United States through partnerships with TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. These world-leading companies are deepening their collaboration with NVIDIA, expanding their businesses, global footprint, and strengthening supply chain resilience.
content after edit:
AI chips and supercomputers require a highly sophisticated supply chain that encompasses advanced manufacturing, packaging, assembly, and testing. NVIDIA’s latest initiatives include partnerships with Amkor and SPIL to build packaging and test operations in Arizona.

Over the next four years, NVIDIA aims to produce up to $500 billion worth of AI infrastructure in the U.S., working with TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. These global leaders are strengthening their collaboration with NVIDIA, expanding operations, enhancing global presence, and increasing supply chain resilience.

[Script for Presenter]

Today’s AI chips are at the heart of an incredibly complex supply chain. They depend on cutting-edge manufacturing, packaging, and testing capabilities. NVIDIA is working closely with companies like Amkor and SPIL to establish some of these vital processes right here in Arizona. This is an important move not only for technological advancement but also for strengthening America’s infrastructure. 

Looking ahead, NVIDIA expects to ramp up production massively—up to $500 billion in AI infrastructure—through partnerships with the world’s leading companies such as TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. This network not only supports NVIDIA’s growth but also helps these companies deepen their international footprint and make the global supply chain even more resilient for the future.

edit target content: (No script or speaker notes currently present on slide 3.)
content after edit:
The AI chip and supercomputer supply chain is complex, requiring the use of the most advanced manufacturing, packaging, assembly, and test technologies in the world. To address these demands and support U.S. production, NVIDIA is forming partnerships with Amkor and SPIL for packaging and testing operations located in Arizona. 

Looking ahead, within the next four years, NVIDIA has a plan to produce up to half a trillion dollars' worth of AI infrastructure in the United States. This ambitious goal will be achieved through partnerships with leading global companies, including TSMC, Foxconn, Wistron, Amkor, and SPIL. These industry leaders are deepening their collaboration with NVIDIA, which will help them expand their businesses, increase their global footprint, and strengthen the overall resilience of the AI technology supply chain.
